title: Security
intro: Managing roles and having fine grain control over security privileges gets complex the larger an organisation gets. There is need for a product that provides a simple user interface between a products core functionality and a changing hierarchy structure of people in large & small groups.

blocks.content: 2.3.4. Security

FieldLogs Enterprise's Security Manager allows administrators the ability to create and edit roles that exist within the Enterprise. Members are assigned a role within the Enterprise which dictates their access to various elements of the FieldLogs platform. Roles are given rules that contain extra conditional logic, giving very fine grain control over access to types of Templates, Jobs and more. By default every Enterprise comes with a set of roles already configured to cover a modern SWI workflow. Administrators may wish to edit these default roles by renaming or adding custom rules, or even adding new roles that suit better the enterprise workflow.

The Security Manager is currently in active development and may have some features missing that allow ultimate control over roles and rules. We are working hard on this important aspect and you will see more features appear over time.
2.3.4.1 Roles & the Hierarchy

It's important to understand how a Role is constructed and what it means to assign a role to a member in your Enterprise. Roles consist of security rules that explicitly tells FieldLogs what kind of access rights a role has to certain securable objects.

This differs from the Hierarchy structure in that it allows the ability to define access to functionality and data for members inside a specific group.

blocks.caption:
As an example, let's take another look at our Hierarchy structure. In the subgroup 'OGSubBU1' you will see one manager member and two normal members. Structure-wise the hierarchy shows a manager with two users.

But using Roles we are able to specify a specific role for members of a group that dictates their access rights to data & role in a the Template Edition Platform.

The roles of a member can be added/changed through the member management panel in the middle of the Enterprise screen. Here you can see in more detail that actually we have a distinction between two members that originally appeared to have the same role in the hierarchy. OGUser3 is a template author and OGUser4 is an SME Reviewer.

blocks.content: 2.3.4.2 Configuring roles with rules

Configuring roles can be achieved by navigating to the 'Security' sub-tab when you are on the Enterprise section of the FieldLogs website. Here, the Security Manager provides a simple UI for defining & editing roles with fine grain rules. Let's take a look below in the context of our Enterprise:
Click on the 'Add new rule' button to add new rules to a Role.

Viewing the rules for the roles it will become clear that there can real differences between the roles. The Hierarchy showed these users at the same level in the group but members can have roles to define their relevance to a specific group.

blocks.caption: Here the Author role only has access to data-themed securable objects, with the ability to create Templates and Jobs, yet no access to administration functions of the Enterprise.
The Product Manager role however has addition rules that allow for a certain amount of administration and viewing of Enterprise elements that are relevant to his job.

blocks.content: 2.3.4.3 Types of Securable Objects

blocks.caption: A securable object needs to be selected for a rule. Templates is the default selection.

points.text: Templates & Jobs are the core content that FieldLogs allows users to create using it's platform.
User means the members of FieldLogs Enterprises.
Enterprise is anything do with the Enterprise structure.
Tasks are generated notifications of job assignments & lifecycle stages.
Roles mean security roles.
Lifecycles facilitate collaborative template edition.
Security Exceptions define specific access for a user to a securable object where otherwise it would be denied.
Everything refers to everything above.

blocks.content: 2.3.4.4 Types of Access Rights

blocks.caption: Read is the default access right for newly created rules. Click the dropdown to view rules for a selected Securable object.

points.text: Read refers to the ability to read information.
Write refers to the ability to write new information.
Translate is the act of translating templates, therefore only available for Templates.
Assign is the ability to assign a template or Job to other members.
Acquire data is the ability to acquire data related to a Job or Template.
Edit info refers to the ability to edit meta data relating to Jobs or Templates.
Export is the right to export Job data in Excel format.
Edit logs refers specifically to the right to edit logs attached to a Job.
All applies all the available access rights to the selected securable object.

blocks.content: 2.3.4.5 Access right permissions
Some access rights can grant several access rights at once. The access rights list below shows each access right along with the set of additional access rights that will be granted.

points.text: Read grants read access only.
Write grants read access, write access, translate access (Templates), edit info access, assign access, export access (Jobs), edit logs access (Jobs), and acquire data access (Jobs).
Translate grants read access and translate access.
Assign grants assign access only.
Acquire data grants read access, acquire data acces, and edit logs access (Jobs).
Edit info grants read access and edit info access.
Export grants read access and export access.
Edit logs grants read access and edit logs access.
All grants all access.

blocks.content: Not all access rights are available for all securable objects as it depends on the nature of the object.
2.3.4.6 Effects of roles and rules on the user interface

Fieldlogs dynamically renders the user interface depending on the level of access associated with the user. For example, if OGContractor1 is assigned the Author role then access will be granted to write templates, but access will be denied to delete templates not belonging to OGContractor1. This is reflected in the UI where the delete button will be removed from all UI elements associated with the template being accessed.
2.3.4.7 Examples
Let's go ahead and look at some examples of some key roles and their rule combinations and delve into what they mean.

The Manager Role (above) is a typical administration role that can be used to allows the adminstration of a Group's Members, Templates & Lifecycles within the Enterprise structure. The rule combinations here allow:

points.text: Full administration rights (create, delete, assign, etc) of Templates at the Managers scope in the hierarchy.
Read rights to the Enterprise structure. This would give this role access to the Enterprise tab to view a scoped view of the Enterprise hierarchy.
Full administration rights to manage users within the Manager's scoped Enterprise structure.
Full administration rights to manage Lifecycles within the Manager's scoped Enterprise structure.

blocks.content: The Employee Role example above is a standard rule collection used to provide the necessary rights for a member of an Enterprise to be able to use Enterprise templates. The rule combinations here specifically allow:

points.text: Right to view, run and assign Enterprise Templates.
Full rights to administer Jobs such as creating, deleting, editing, exporting and assigning the continuation of Jobs.
The full ability to view, run and re-assign tasks including creating security exceptions if needed when assigning Tasks to other members within the Employee's Enterprise scope.

blocks.content: A Contractor Role is specifically aimed at temporary or restricted members of an Enterprise that only need access to data within a narrow scope in the Enterprise. With similar rights as an Employee Role, this role can be considered more as a label. The rule combinations here specifically allow:

points.text: Right to view, run and assign Enterprise Templates.
Full rights to administer Jobs such as creating, deleting, editing, exporting and assigning the continuation of Jobs.
The full ability to view, run and re-assign tasks including creating security exceptions if needed when assigning Tasks to other members within the Contractor's Enterprise scope.

blocks.content: 2.3.4.8 Security Exceptions

In some situations an administrator or privileged user may find it necessary to allow a user access to a particular resource not located on the same branch of the user. As this breaks the default restrictions of the enterprise hierarchy authorisation, a security exception needs to be created telling the system that access should be granted in this particular case. Repositories can’t be used as this would grant multiple users access to the resource.

blocks.caption: Consider a situation where OGUser7 would like to assign a task to OGContractor1. As OGContractor1 is located lower in the hierarchy structure, access will be denied to the resource associated with the assign task. The only way to bypass this constraint is to create a security exception for OGContractor1 to the resource.

To create a security exception, we first need to navigate to the cell of the item. On the right, there will be a dropdown list of actions, one of which is the Assign action. When the assign button is clicked, the assign task popup will appear. Here, we can select the user we want to assign the resource to. In OGUser7’s case, OGContractor1 will be selected. This will prompt the creation of a security exception for OGContractor1.

For security reasons, Fieldlogs does now allow for the direct creation of security exceptions. Instead, Fieldlogs will present the option to create a security exception in the case where the system knows that the assignee of the task will not have access to the resource.

blocks.content: An assignee will also have the ability to request access to the resource from the assignor. This can achieved by clicking on the fix button in the task inbox section.

blocks.caption: An assignee will also have the ability to request access to the resource from the assignor. This can achieved by clicking on the fix button in the task inbox section. This will notify the assignor that the assignee does not have access.

blocks.content: A Template or Job much be shared or public, otherwise access will continue to be denied even with the security exception.
2.3.4.8.1 Security Exceptions Manager

At any time, created security exceptions can be managed via the Security Exceptions Manager subsection under the Enterprise section. Here we can see the list of security exceptions created throughout the enterprise. Privileged users located higher in the hierarchy will have access to view security exceptions created by users located lower down in the hierarchy. In the manager we can see, and modify a few of, the following attributes associated with security exception:

points.text: The type of security exception created.
The creator (grantor) of the exception.
The grantee (granted to) of the exception.
The start and end date during which the exception will grant access.
The resource (item) being accessed.
Whether or not the exception is currently enabled.
